citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The program of veterinary care states that all birds that have no history of vaccine status, be vaccinated for West Nile
Virus. No vaccine records are available for review for "Mozart", an adult umbrella cockatoo and the facility representative
states the animal has not been vaccinated for West Nile Virus. Failure to follow the program of veterinary care set by the
attending veterinarian may result in illness or injury to animals. Exhibitors shall maintain programs of adequate veterinary
care that include the appropriate methods to prevent, control and treat diseases and injuries.

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Multiple adult fallow deer were observed to have single round raised skin masses on their necks. One deer had a mass
located low on the neck that had hair loss on the surface and the skin appeared red. The animals were active and
otherwise apparently healthy. The facility representative stated that the attending veterinarian had diagnosed previous
lesions similar in appearance in the herd and indicated the masses were removed when located close to the eyes. The
facility representative conveyed that the masses are monitored but cannot recall the last time they updated the attending
veterinarian on the masses.
Failure to provide direct and frequent information on animal health to the attending veterinarian may result in prolongation
of disease or spread of infectious disease. Each exhibitor shall observe all animals daily and provide direct and frequent
communication on the problems of animal health and well-being to the attending veterinarian.

Acquisition records for 3 domestic pigs and the disposition record for 1 wallaby were not available for review at time of
inspection. Appropriate documentation of regulated animals is essential for proper identification, tracking of animals and
for APHIS Officials to be able to carry out their duties. Exhibitors shall make and maintain complete records regarding the
details of the acquisition and disposition of animals in their possession in order to account for all animal transfers and the
sources of the animals.

The raised caged ledge attached to the side of the primary enclosure for "Cleo" the adult common marmoset has heavy
rusting and flaking of the metal frame. Rusty surfaces cannot be effectively cleaned and sanitized. Any surfaces that
come into contact with nonhuman primates must be free of excessive rust that prevents the required cleaning and
sanitization, or that affects the structural strength of the surface.

Multiple areas of the wooden frame around the door of the primary enclosure for an adult umbrella cockatoo, "Mozart",
are heavily chewed, worn or missing and exposing a metal screw. Excessive wearing of the housing material can
compromise structural strength, present roughened and jagged surfaces where it is possible for the birds to injure
themselves, and prevent proper cleaning and sanitization of a surface. Interior surfaces that come into contact with birds
must be free of rust or damage that affects the structural integrity of the surface or prevents cleaning.

There are multiple sharp points and edges present in the primary enclosure for "Mozart", an adult umbrella cockatoo.
Multiple metal wires are hanging from the sides of the primary enclosure and pointing inward. A metal screw
approximately 1 inch in length is exposed by the door due to part of the wooden frame is missing. Sheet metal is used as
paneling for many wall surfaces inside the primary enclosure and some edges are exposed, bent inward and appear
jagged. Sharp points and edges may cause injury to the animal. The primary enclosure must be kept in good repair and
have no sharp points or edges that could injure the bird.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
A singly housed adult umbrella cockatoo, "Mozart", has a large patch of missing feathers on the abdomen that the facility
representative indicates hasn't had any regrowth. In the avian environment enhancement plan, there is no documentation
of special attention given to the animal based on its appearance and sign of being in psychological distress. The plan
does address additional enrichment for this individually housed social species of bird. Failure to fully develop and
document a plan for special consideration birds in all applicable categories may result in inadequate or intermittent care in
promoting and addressing their psychological well-being. Certain birds must be provided special attention regarding
enhancement of their environment in accordance with the instructions of the attending veterinarian, which includes birds
that show signs of being in psychological distress through behavior or appearance.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by September 7th, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the
license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License
Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The program of veterinary care states that all birds that have no history of vaccine status, be vaccinated for West Nile 
Virus. No vaccine records are available for review for "Mozart", an adult umbrella cockatoo and the facility representative 
states the animal has not been vaccinated for West Nile Virus. Failure to follow the program of veterinary care set by the 
attending veterinarian may result in illness or injury to animals. Exhibitors shall maintain programs of adequate veterinary 
care that include the appropriate methods to prevent, control and treat diseases and injuries. 
2.40(b)(3) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Multiple adult fallow deer were observed to have single round raised skin masses on their necks. One deer had a mass 
located low on the neck that had hair loss on the surface and the skin appeared red. The animals were active and

lesions similar in appearance in the herd and indicated the masses were removed when located close to the eyes. The

Failure to provide direct and frequent information on animal health to the attending veterinarian may result in prolongation 
of disease or spread of infectious disease. Each exhibitor shall observe all animals daily and provide direct and frequent 
communication on the problems of animal health and well-being to the attending veterinarian. 
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
Acquisition records for 3 domestic pigs and the disposition record for 1 wallaby were not available for review at time of 
inspection. Appropriate documentation of regulated animals is essential for proper identification, tracking of animals and 
for APHIS Officials to be able to carry out their duties. Exhibitors shall make and maintain complete records regarding the 
details of the acquisition and disposition of animals in their possession in order to account for all animal transfers and the 
sources of the animals.

3.75(c)(1)(i) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
The raised caged ledge attached to the side of the primary enclosure for "Cleo" the adult common marmoset has heavy 
rusting and flaking of the metal frame. Rusty surfaces cannot be effectively cleaned and sanitized. Any surfaces that 
come into contact with nonhuman primates must be free of excessive rust that prevents the required cleaning and

3.150(c)(2) 
   
Facilities, general. 
Multiple areas of the wooden frame around the door of the primary enclosure for an adult umbrella cockatoo, "Mozart", 
are heavily chewed, worn or missing and exposing a metal screw. Excessive wearing of the housing material can 
compromise structural strength, present roughened and jagged surfaces where it is possible for the birds to injure 
themselves, and prevent proper cleaning and sanitization of a surface. Interior surfaces that come into contact with birds 
must be free of rust or damage that affects the structural integrity of the surface or prevents cleaning. 
3.153(a)(1)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
There are multiple sharp points and edges present in the primary enclosure for "Mozart", an adult umbrella cockatoo. 
Multiple metal wires are hanging from the sides of the primary enclosure and pointing inward. A metal screw 
approximately 1 inch in length is exposed by the door due to part of the wooden frame is missing. Sheet metal is used as

jagged. Sharp points and edges may cause injury to the animal. The primary enclosure must be kept in good repair and

3.154(c)(2) 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
A singly housed adult umbrella cockatoo, "Mozart", has a large patch of missing feathers on the abdomen that the facility 
representative indicates hasn't had any regrowth. In the avian environment enhancement plan, there is no documentation 
of special attention given to the animal based on its appearance and sign of being in psychological distress. The plan

promoting and addressing their psychological well-being. Certain birds must be provided special attention regarding

that show signs of being in psychological distress through behavior or appearance. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by September 7th, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the

license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License 
Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
